text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

--Education given as part of retraining schemes for the unemployed can cost as much as five times as much as formal higher education -- university medical studies for example -- and has only limited effect on the candidate's future job and pay prospects.
--Shipping group A.P. Moeller's shares rose by 10 percent in May alone and are now worth a total of close to 100 billion crowns, but there is no apparent explanation for the rise.
--The government intends to increase the tax it levies on owner-occupiers while lowering income tax.
--BG Bank sees Neurosearch as undervalued at 387 crowns and says that the share could go as high as 1,242 crowns.
--Regulators are looking at the J.Lauritzen shipping group's JL Fund, which allegedly invested in a Lauritzen subsidiary without the necessary permission.

--Increasing passenger traffic on SAS at the start of the second quarter is leading several analysts to upgrade their forecasts for the airline. SAS is also promising more information for investors in future.

-- Twenty-eight percent of workers are not paid by their former employers for the first two days out of work uncovered by unemployment benefit, as welfare rules stipulate. Public sector employers are the worst offenders, a study by the unemployment insurance directorate says, with 56 percent of state and local authority workplaces failing to pay up.
--The opposition Conservatives have withdrawn their support for a government proposal to allow businesses to plan their own health and safety conditions.
